title: Firefox Ubuntu/Snap YouTube Livestream plays for 30 seconds then error
content:
As per the title, I can play a YouTube LiveStream this was the one I was viewing today PostOffice Inquiry https://www.youtube.com/@postofficehorizonitinquiry947 and SkyNews which play fine for about 20 seconds then fail with an error message that "Something went wrong, please try again latter". Refreshing the YouTube page the Livestream then plays another 20 seconds of the livestream then fails again with the same error message.

Other non LiveStream YouTube videos play fine

I have disabled all extensions, tried firefox troubleshooting mode, tried opening in a private window, tried logged in and out of YouTube account. The same thing happens (stream plays then ends after 20 seconds).

The same YouTube Livestram URLs work fine in Chrome Browser

system: Linux 24.10 Beta Firefox Snap version 130..0.1

title: Problema aggiornamento firefox
content: Buongiorno a tutti. Mi scuso per la mia incompetenza ma non riesco a risolvere un problema. Ho installato da pochi giorni linux 22 vilma. Chiaramente installato anche firefox compreso nel sistema. Avendo riscontrato qualche problema di lentezza in firefox, vorrei provare a verificare se ci sono aggiornamenti, visto che il browser non si aggiorna mai automaticamente. Il problema è che quando apro la pagina per cercare gli aggiornamenti (aiuto-informazioni su firefox nel menu in alto a destra con le tre barrette per intenderci), dove dovrenbbe esserci la voce per aggiornare firefox c'è invece la scritta "Aggiornamenti disattivati dalla tua organizzazione". Preciso che il computer è autonomo e non collegato a nessuna organizzazioe o rete locale. Come posso risolvere il problema? Sono giorni che cerco sul web ma non ho trovato la soluzione. Qualcuno può darmi una soluzione? Ripeto che mi scuso per la mia incompetenza. Grazie
creator: romeo.ricci.62

title: Does Firefox support service workers for videos loaded from a video element?
content:
I'm trying to use a service worker to add some additional headers to image and video requests but on Firefox the fetch event is only being invoked for the images and not the videos. On Chrome it is called for both.

I cannot find any documentation that says Firefox does not support service workers for video but this appears to be the case. Can anybody point me in the right direction?

sw.js 'use strict';

self.addEventListener("install", (event) => { 

 // Force the newly installed service worker to replace any earlier version  self.skipWaiting();

});

self.addEventListener("activate", (event) => { 

 // Activate the service worker immediately in all clients    event.waitUntil(self.clients.claim());

});

self.addEventListener('fetch', (event) => { 

 console.log(`SW.js: ${event.request.url}`);  const updatedHeaders = new Headers(event.request.headers);  //updatedHeaders.set('Accept', '*');  // Create a new request object with the updated headers  const updatedRequest = new Request(event.request, {    headers: updatedHeaders  });  event.respondWith(fetch(updatedRequest));

});

title: How to keep the same internal UUID by installing a Firefox add-on in unlisted mode?
content:
Good morning,

I am developing a browser add-on for Firefox. I would like to ask a question. Is it possible to publish the add-on in an unlisted way, but making sure that when it is installed in the browser it always maintains the same internal UUID (which does not correspond to the add-on ID)? If it is not possible to do this by publishing it unlisted, would it be possible to do so by publishing it in your store in a listed way?

I await your kind reply Thank you, best regards

title: Firefox acting weirdly on my computer. Loses tabs, opens new windows with the tabs, does not completely close
content:
Hi I replaced chrome with firefox last 2 days but I am having a host of problems since then I only use ublock origin as addon. This one I always used on chrome too OK so I have checked "open previous windows and tabs" but it is not respected. I open firefox, it's blank I look into the little icon to the top left and see a list of tabs that are split between a window 1 (current) and another window.

So, it informs me that magically I have more than 1 window firefox open I am not aware of.

Next, closing firefox, doesn't actually close it. I mean the usual x, alt-f4 In the task manager I still see firefox; some 8-12 processes. So this could mean that when I hit firefox shortcut thinking I have no firefox open and waiting to come back to my tabs, I get a blank firefox.

Next, wishing to perform an uninstall, I ...can't. It says firefox is running, it must first be ended(!) and if I want instead a cleanup

Next, some weirder things. With firefox open, opening spotify web in a new tab triggered the opening of a new firefox window with tabs I deemed lost.

I only use a single profile, that addon and all happens on a Windows 10 x64 machine with i5, 16GB RAM and NVME storage on which the single most recent modification was the replacement of chrome with firefox.

title: Using policies.json to manage individual profiles on linux
content:
I'm having trouble using the policies.json file to manage individual profiles on Linux. I've come across sources that suggest placing the distribution/policies.json file in the profile folder should work, but I can't seem to get it to function as expected.

My use case is to create a separate profile that can only connect to localhost.

I have a few questions:

  • Is there a specific way to use policies.json for managing individual profiles on Linux? If so, what is the correct method?
  • Can the location where Firefox looks for the policies.json file be overwritten for a new process? If yes, how can this be achieved?

title: ads telemetry
content: For over a decade, I trusted Firefox implicitly, believing in your unwavering commitment to user privacy and respect. Today, that trust was shattered when I opened my browser to find ads plastered across my homepage. This isn't just an annoyance; it's a betrayal of the very principles that drew me to your software. You've reduced yourselves to the same level as the data-hungry corporations you once stood against. It's not just disappointing—it's despicable. I will not stand by and accept this violation. Consider this my farewell, as I cannot in good conscience continue to use a product that so blatantly disregards its users. You've lost more than just a customer; you've lost the respect and loyalty of someone who once championed your cause.
creator: pedrobackard
